citation.abstract: Temperature sensitive cdc1(ts) mutants are reported to stop the cell cycle upon shift to 30°C in early G2, i.e. as small budded cells having completed DNA replication but unable to duplicate the spindle pole body. A recent report showed that PGAP5, a human homologue of CDC1, acts as a phosphodiesterase removing an ethanolaminephosphate from mannose 2 of the GPI anchor, thus permitting efficient ER to Golgi transport of GPI proteins. We find that the essential CDC1 gene can be deleted in mcd4∆ cells, which do not attach ethanolaminephosphate to mannose 1 of the GPI anchor, suggesting that Cdc1 removes the ethanolaminephosphate added by Mcd4. Cdc1-314(ts) mutants do not accumulate GPI proteins in the ER but have a partial secretion block later in the secretory pathway. Growth tests and the genetic interaction profile of cdc1-314(ts) pinpoint a distinct cell wall defect. Osmotic support restores GPI-protein secretion and actin polarization but not growth. Cell walls of cdc1-314(ts) mutants contain large amounts of GPI proteins that are easily released by β-glucanases, not attached to cell wall β1,6-glucans and retain their original GPI anchor lipid. This suggests that the presumed transglycosidases Dfg5 and Dcw1 of cdc1-314(ts) transfer GPI-proteins to cell wall β1,6-glucans inefficiently.
citation.title: Cdc1 removes the ethanolaminephosphate of the first mannose of GPI anchors and thereby facilitates the integration of GPI proteins into the yeast cell wall.
